stem: The nurse is assessing a 9-month-old infant during a well-child visit. Based on the following findings, indicate which developmental milestone is expected for each age range.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
**SBAR - Pediatric Well-Child Visit**

**Patient:** Baby Michael, 9 months old
**Date/Time:** 2026-07-20 14:30
**Nurse:** Sarah Miller, RN

**Situation (14:30):** Michael is here for a routine 9-month well-child check-up. Parents report he is generally healthy and meeting milestones. No acute concerns reported today.

**Background (14:32):** Michael was born at term, with no complications during pregnancy or delivery. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations. He is primarily breastfed, supplemented with pureed foods. Parents deny any allergies. Previous weight and height were within normal limits. He sits unsupported. Rolls from tummy to back. Babbles frequently.

**Assessment (14:45):** Physical exam reveals a healthy, active infant. He is alert and responsive. Weight and height are appropriate for age. He is able to transfer objects from one hand to the other. He does not yet crawl. He pulls to stand briefly while holding onto furniture. He is able to say "mama" and "dada" nonspecifically. He responds to his name.

**Recommendation (14:50):** Continue current feeding plan. Encourage floor time to promote crawling. Follow-up appointment scheduled for 12 months. Review anticipatory guidance for safety and nutrition. Discuss upcoming vaccinations. Answer any parental questions/concerns. Parents verbalize understanding and agreement with plan.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: No lab results available for this visit.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
**General:** Alert, active, and in no acute distress.
**HEENT:** Head normocephalic, fontanelles open and soft. Eyes clear, PERRL. Ears clear. Nose patent. Mouth and throat clear.
**Cardiovascular:** Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
**Respiratory:** Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
**Gastrointestinal:** Abdomen soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present.
**Musculoskeletal:** Moves all extremities equally. Able to sit unsupported. Pulls to stand briefly while holding onto furniture. Transfers objects hand-to-hand.
**Neurological:** Age-appropriate reflexes present. Responds to name.

rows.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other.

rationale.correct: The correct answers reflect typical developmental milestones for the specified age ranges. Accurate assessment of developmental milestones is crucial for identifying potential developmental delays and ensuring appropriate interventions are implemented.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the expected age ranges for specific developmental milestones. It is important to understand the typical progression of development to identify deviations that may require further evaluation.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Sitting unsupported is typically achieved around 6 months of age. This milestone demonstrates improved trunk control and balance.

answerBreakdown.text: Transfers objects from one hand to the other.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Transferring objects from one hand to the other is typically achieved around 6 months of age. This indicates developing fine motor skills and coordination.
Pulling to stand is typically achieved around 9 months of age. This milestone indicates developing leg strength and gross motor skills.
Saying 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically is typically achieved around 9 months of age. This milestone reflects early language development and vocalization.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones are guidelines, and variations can occur. It is crucial to assess the whole child and consider individual differences.
Early identification of developmental delays allows for timely intervention and support.
Parental input is valuable in assessing a child's developmental progress.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the order in which milestones are achieved. For example, thinking pulling to stand occurs before sitting unsupported.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Review the typical sequence of motor development milestones and the age ranges in which they are generally achieved.

mnemonic.title: SPOTS
mnemonic.expansion: Sitting (6 months), Pincer Grasp (9 months), Object Permanence (9 months), Transfers Objects (6 months), Standing (12 months)
